page.title: 11THE COMMON RIDING
page.content: The patrols of the Town's lands were carried out on an regular basis as and when it was felt necessary. The patrols became known as a rideout and the whole event became formalised in a Common Riding. The frequency of the rideout diminished until it was only an annual event. Until this year (1985) only the North Marches were ridden, however the 450th anniversary of the granting off the Royal Charter was used as reason to send riders once again round the traditional route. Most of the route covered is within this block of the Domesday project. Common Ridings are a unique feature of the Border towns and many people ffrom all over the world will return at the time of the Common Riding. The Standard Bearer is elected from amongst the local young men and must be unmarried.
